GTB SPECIAL DV PROJECT
GTB SPECIAL DV PROJECT

FOLLOWING THE SUPREME COURTS 1978 DECISION IN OLIPHANT V. SUQUAMISH TRIBE, TRIBES LACKED CRIMINAL JURISDICTION TO PROSECUTE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND DATING VIOLENCE COMMITTED IN INDIAN COUNTRY BY NON-INDIAN ABUSERS.  VAWA 2013 INCLUDED AN HISTORIC PROVISION THAT RECOGNIZED THE AUTHORITY OF PARTICIPATING TRIBES TO EXERCISE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ) OVER CERTAIN DEFENDANTS, REGARDLESS OF THEIR INDIAN OR NON-INDIAN STATUS, WHO COMMIT CRIMES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE OR DATING VIOLENCE OR VIOLATE CERTAIN PROTECTION ORDERS IN INDIAN COUNTRY.  THE ACT ALSO SPECIFIED THE RIGHTS THAT A PARTICIPATING TRIBE MUST PROVIDE TO DEFENDANTS IN SDVCJ CASES. 

THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION PROGRAM IS DESIGNED TO ASSIST TRIBES IN EXERCISING SDVCJ.  THROUGH THIS GRANT PROGRAM, INDIAN TRIBES WILL RECEIVE SUPPORT AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PLANNING, DEVELOPING AND IMPLEMENTING CHANGES IN THEIR CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEMS NECESSARY TO EXERCISE SDVCJ, AS WELL AS FUNDS TO EXERCISE SDVCJ.  THE PROGRAM ENCOURAGES COLLABORATIONS AMONG TRIBAL LEADERSHIP, TRIBAL COURTS, TRIBAL PROSECUTORS, TRIBAL ATTORNEYS, TRIBAL DEFENDERS, LAW ENFORCEMENT, PROBATION, SERVICE PROVIDERS, AND OTHER PARTNERS TO ENSURE THAT NON-INDIANS WHO COMMIT CRIMES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, DATING VIOLENCE, AND VIOLATIONS OF PROTECTION ORDERS ARE HELD ACCOUNTABLE.  THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION PROGRAM ENCOURAGES THE COORDINATED INVOLVEMENT OF THE ENTIRE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM AND VICTIM SERVICE PROVIDERS TO INCORPORATE SYSTEMIC CHANGE THAT ENSURES VICTIM SAFETY AND OFFENDER ACCOUNTABILITY.

THE TULALIP TRIBES OF WASHINGTON IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED TRIBAL GOVERNMENT WHICH HAS JURISDICTION OVER LANDS WHICH MEET THE DEFINITION OF "INDIAN COUNTRY" LOCATED ABOUT 30 MILES NORTH OF SEATTLE, WASHINGTON.  THE DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE HAS DESIGNATED THE TULALIP TRIBES AS A PARTICIPANT TRIBE IN THE PILOT PROJECT ESTABLISHED BY THE VIOLENCE AGAINST WOMEN REAUTHORIZATION ACT OF 2013. AS A PILOT PROJECT TRIBE, THE TULALIP TRIBES HAS THE EXISTING LAWS, INFRASTRUCTURE, AND STAFF QUALIFIED TO EXERCISE THE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ).  THE TULALIP TRIBES, AND ITS PARTNERS, ARE DETERMINED TO FURTHER DEVELOP AND EXERCISE THEIR SDVCJ.  COLLABORATIVE PARTNERS FOR THE TULALIP TRIBES SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION PROJECT INCLUDE: BOARD OF DIRECTORS, CHIEF JUDGE, OFFICE OF RESERVATION ATTORNEY  PROSECUTORS DIVISION, RESERVATION ATTORNEY, CHIEF OF POLICE, AND THE LEGACY OF HEALING PROGRAM DIRECTOR.  THE PROJECT WILL STRENGTHEN THE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM IN EXERCISING SDVCJ, INCLUDING EFFORTS FOCUSED ON PROSECUTION AND CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE SERVICES AND ASSISTANCE FOR VICTIMS AND THEIR FAMILIES BY PROVIDING A VICTIM SERVICES COORDINATOR WITHIN THE PROSECUTORS OFFICE AND UTILIZING GPS MONITORING TO TRACK AND MONITOR DEFENDANTS. SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO: 1) HIRE PERSONNEL FOR THE POSITION CREATED THROUGH THE PROJECT; 2) DEVELOPING AND FINE-TUNING EXISTING PROCESSES IN EXERCISING SDVCJ; 3) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT PROCESSES FOR GPS MONITORING OF OFFENDERS; 4) EVALUATE PROCESSES AND PROVIDE A REPORT OF PROJECT SUCCESSES, LESSONS LEARNED, AND NEXT STEPS; 5) CONTINUE PARTICIPATION IN THE INTER-TRIBAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WORKING GROUP (ITWG) ON SDVCJ; AND 6) PARTICIPATION IN ON-SITE AND OTHER TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OPPORTUNITIES.

THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS AWARD IS 36 MONTHS.

CA/NCF
TULALIP TRIBES SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION
CHEHALIS TRIBE VAWA DV JURISDICTION IMPLEMENTATION

FOLLOWING THE SUPREME COURTS 1978 DECISION IN OLIPHANT V. SUQUAMISH TRIBE, TRIBES LACKED CRIMINAL JURISDICTION TO PROSECUTE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE AND DATING VIOLENCE COMMITTED IN INDIAN COUNTRY BY NON-INDIAN ABUSERS.  VAWA 2013 INCLUDED AN HISTORIC PROVISION THAT RECOGNIZED THE AUTHORITY OF PARTICIPATING TRIBES TO EXERCISE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ) OVER CERTAIN DEFENDANTS, REGARDLESS OF THEIR INDIAN OR NON-INDIAN STATUS, WHO COMMIT CRIMES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE OR DATING VIOLENCE OR VIOLATE CERTAIN PROTECTION ORDERS IN INDIAN COUNTRY.  THE ACT ALSO SPECIFIED THE RIGHTS THAT A PARTICIPATING TRIBE MUST PROVIDE TO DEFENDANTS IN SDVCJ CASES.

THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION PROGRAM ENCOURAGES THE COORDINATED INVOLVEMENT OF THE ENTIRE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM AND VICTIM SERVICE PROVIDERS TO INCORPORATE SYSTEMIC CHANGE THAT ENSURES VICTIM SAFETY AND OFFENDER ACCOUNTABILITY.

THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS (LTBB) IS A FEDERALLY RECOGNIZED INDIAN TRIBE LOCATED IN THE NORTHERN TIP OF MICHIGANS LOWER PENINSULA. THE LTBB HAS JURISDICTION OVER LANDS WHICH MEET THE DEFINITION OF "INDIAN COUNTRY" WITHIN ITS THREE COUNTY SERVICE AREA.  LTBB PASSED A CODE IMPLEMENTING SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ) ON MARCH 9, 2015. THE LTBB, AND ITS INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL PARTNERS, ARE DETERMINED TO PLAN, DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT, AND EXERCISE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ).  COLLABORATIVE PARTNERS FOR THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS' SERVICE ENHANCEMENTS FOR SDVCJ PROJECT INCLUDE:  TRIBAL COUNCIL, TRIBAL COURT DOMESTIC VIOLENCE DOCKET COORDINATOR, TRIBAL COURT ADMINISTRATOR, LTBB CHIEF JUDGE, LTBB TRIBAL ADMINISTRATOR, LTBB PROSECUTING ATTORNEY, LTBB CHIEF OF POLICE, LTBB BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES, LTBB SURVIVOR OUTREACH SERVICES, LTBB HEALTH DEPARTMENT, AND THEIR EXTERNAL PARTNER, THE WOMENS RESOURCE CENTER OF NORTHERN MICHIGAN.  THE LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS' SERVICE ENHANCEMENTS FOR SDVCJ PROJECT PARTNERS WILL ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON THE FOLLOWING PURPOSES: 1) STRENGTHEN LTBB TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEMS; 2) PROVIDE INDIGENT CRIMINAL DEFENDANTS, IN SDVCJ PROCEEDINGS, WITH EFFECTIVE ASSISTANCE OF LICENSED DEFENSE COUNSEL; AND 3) ENSURE JURORS, IN SDVCJ PROCEEDINGS, ARE SUMMONED, SELECTED, AND INSTRUCTED APPROPRIATELY.  SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES INCLUDE BUT ARE NOT LIMITED TO ENHANCEMENTS TO STRENGTHEN LTBBS ABILITY TO EXERCISE SPECIAL JURISDICTION: 1) FINALIZE ALL POLICIES AND PROCEDURES SURROUNDING SDVCJ; 2) SOLIDIFY SERVICES BY PROVIDING CULTURALLY-APPROPRIATE ASSISTANCE TO VICTIMS AND THEIR FAMILIES; 3) DEVELOP AND IMPLEMENT A PROCESS FOR INDIGENT DEFENDANTS; 4) MAINTAIN THE DV COURT DOCKET; 5) PROVIDE STRENGTHENED OFFENDER SURVEILLANCE; 6) DEVELOP AND FINALIZE JURY POOL PROCESSES; 7) CONTINUE PARTICIPATION IN THE INTER-TRIBAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WORKING GROUP (ITWG) ON SDVCJ;  8) PARTICIPATE IN ON-SITE AND OTHER TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OPPORTUNITIES; AND 9) SUBMIT THE SDVCJ QUESTIONNAIRE AND SUPPORTING CERTIFICATIONS FOR OVW REVIEW AND APPROVAL.

THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS AWARD IS 36 MONTHS.

CA/NCF
LITTLE TRAVERSE BAY BANDS OF ODAWA INDIANS'' SERVICE ENHANCEMENTS FOR SDVCJ PROJECT
YUROK TRIBE DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JUSRISDICTION
THIS GRANT WILL PROVIDE THE CRITICAL STIMULUS NEEDED FOR PGST TO PREPARE FOR AND EXERCISE SDVCJ.
DOMESTIC VIOLENCE JURISDICTION PROJECT

THROUGH THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION GRANT PROGRAM, RECIPIENTS RECEIVE SUPPORT TO EXERCISE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OVER CERTAIN NON-INDIANS PURSUANT TO THE INDIAN CIVIL RIGHTS ACT (ICRA), AS AMENDED, ALONG WITH TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTING CHANGES IN THEIR CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEMS NECESSARY TO EXERCISE THE JURISDICTION. GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE COMMITTED TO EXERCISING THIS JURISDICTION TO ENSURE THAT VICTIMS FIND SAFETY AND JUSTICE AND THAT NON-INDIANS WHO COMMIT APPLICABLE CRIMES WITHIN THEIR JURISDICTION ARE HELD ACCOUNTABLE. BEGINNING ON OCTOBER 1, 2022, THE CRIMES COVERED BY THIS JURISDICTION ARE: ASSAULT OF TRIBAL JUSTICE PERSONNEL; CHILD VIOLENCE; DATING VIOLENCE; DOMESTIC VIOLENCE; OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE; SEXUAL VIOLENCE; SEX TRAFFICKING; STALKING; AND VIOLATION OF A PROTECTION ORDER WHERE THE VICTIM IS AN INDIAN (EXCEPT FOR ASSAULT OF TRIBAL JUSTICE PERSONNEL OR OBSTRUCTION OF JUSTICE, WHERE THE VICTIM NEED NOT BE AN INDIAN). GRANT RECIPIENTS AND PROJECT PARTNERS ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON STRENGTHENING THE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM IN ORDER TO EXERCISE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION OVER NON-INDIAN OFFENDERS PURSUANT TO ICRA, AS AMENDED; PROVIDING INDIGENT CRIMINAL DEFENDANTS WITH EFFECTIVE ASSISTANCE OF LICENSED DEFENSE COUNSEL; ENSURING JURORS ARE SUMMONED, SELECTED, AND INSTRUCTED APPROPRIATELY; AND ACCORDING VICTIMS RIGHTS THAT ARE SIMILAR TO THE RIGHTS OF A CRIME VICTIM DESCRIBED IN SECTION 3771(A) OF TITLE 18. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COMPLETING THE REQUIRED PLANNING PERIOD TO ENGAGE REQUIRED AND KEY PARTNERS IN A PLANNING PROCESS AND MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING DEVELOPMENT; PARTICIPATING IN THE INTER-TRIBAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WORKING GROUP (ITWG); PARTICIPATING IN ON-SITE AND OTHER TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OPPORTUNITIES; AND SUBMITTING THE SUPPORTING CERTIFICATIONS FOR OVW REVIEW AND APPROVAL, IF REQUIRED.

THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS AWARD IS 36 MONTHS.

FY 2022 SUPPORT FOR TRIBES EXERCISING SDVCJ SPECIAL INITIATIVE

THROUGH THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION GRANT PROGRAM, RECIPIENTS RECEIVE SUPPORT TO EXERCISE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ) AND TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE NECESSARY TO EXERCISE THE JURISDICTION. GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE COMMITTED TO EXERCISING SDVCJ TO ENSURE THAT VICTIMS FIND SAFETY AND JUSTICE AND THAT NON-INDIANS WHO COMMIT CRIMES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, DATING VIOLENCE, AND VIOLATIONS OF PROTECTION ORDERS WITHIN THEIR JURISDICTION ARE HELD ACCOUNTABLE. THROUGH THIS SPECIAL INITIATIVE TRIBES CURRENTLY EXERCISING THE JURISDICTION RECEIVE FUNDING TO DEFRAY COSTS RESULTING FROM THE EXERCISE OF SDVCJ, INCLUDING COSTS ASSOCIATED WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT, PROSECUTION, TRIAL AND APPELLATE COURTS, PROBATION SYSTEMS, DETENTION AND CORRECTION FACILITIES (INCLUDING MEDICAL CARE), ALTERNATIVE REHABILITATION, CULTURALLY APPROPRIATE ASSISTANCE FOR VICTIMS AND THEIR FAMILIES, PROVIDING DEFENSE COUNSEL TO INDIGENT CRIMINAL DEFENDANTS, AND EMPANELING JURIES. THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS AWARD IS 12 MONTHS.

COMANCHE NATION SPECIAL JURISDICTION PROJECT

THROUGH THE TRIBAL JURISDICTION GRANT PROGRAM, RECIPIENTS RECEIVE SUPPORT TO EXERCISE SPECIAL DOMESTIC VIOLENCE CRIMINAL JURISDICTION (SDVCJ) AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR PLANNING AND IMPLEMENTING CHANGES IN THEIR CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEMS NECESSARY TO EXERCISE THE JURISDICTION. GRANT RECIPIENTS ARE COMMITTED TO EXERCISING SDVCJ TO ENSURE THAT VICTIMS FIND SAFETY AND JUSTICE AND THAT NON-INDIANS WHO COMMIT CRIMES OF DOMESTIC VIOLENCE, DATING VIOLENCE, AND VIOLATIONS OF PROTECTION ORDERS WITHIN THEIR JURISDICTION ARE HELD ACCOUNTABLE. GRANT RECIPIENTS AND PROJECT PARTNERS ENGAGE IN ACTIVITIES FOCUSED ON STRENGTHENING THE TRIBAL CRIMINAL JUSTICE SYSTEM IN ORDER TO EXERCISE SDVCJ; PROVIDING INDIGENT CRIMINAL DEFENDANTS IN SDVCJ PROCEEDINGS WITH EFFECTIVE ASSISTANCE OF LICENSED DEFENSE COUNSEL; ENSURING JURORS ARE SUMMONED, SELECTED, AND INSTRUCTED APPROPRIATELY; AND ACCORDING VICTIM’S RIGHTS THAT ARE SIMILAR TO THE RIGHTS OF A CRIME VICTIM DESCRIBED IN SECTION 3771(A) OF TITLE 18. ADDITIONAL ACTIVITIES INCLUDE COMPLETING THE REQUIRED PLANNING PERIOD TO ENGAGE REQUIRED AND KEY PARTNERS IN A PLANNING PROCESS AND MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING DEVELOPMENT; PARTICIPATING IN THE INTER-TRIBAL TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE WORKING GROUP (ITWG) ON SDVCJ; PARTICIPATING IN ON-SITE AND OTHER TRAINING AND TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE OPPORTUNITIES; AND SUBMITTING THE SDVCJ SUPPORTING CERTIFICATIONS FOR OVW REVIEW AND APPROVAL, IF REQUIRED. 

THE TIMING FOR PERFORMANCE OF THIS AWARD IS 36 MONTHS.
